cards.front: What are Newton's laws of motion?
cards.back: [First Law] An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force. [Second Law] The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. F = ma. [Third Law] For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.stem: Which of the following statements correctly describes Newton's second law?
options: Force equals mass times acceleration (F = ma)
Acceleration equals force divided by mass (a = F/m)
Work equals force times distance (W = Fd)
Energy equals force squared over mass (E = F^2 / m)
questions.rationale: Newton's second law states that the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion
insights.takeaway: Fundamental laws describing the relationships among a body and the forces acting upon it, including the law of inertia, the law of acceleration, and the law of action and reaction.

cards.front: What is Newton's first law of motion?
cards.back: Newton's First Law, also known as the law of inertia, states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

cards.front: What is Newton's second law of motion?
cards.back: Newton's Second Law states that the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. The formula is F = ma.

cards.front: What is Newton's third law of motion?
cards.back: Newton's Third Law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

insights.title: First Law of Motion (Law of Inertia)
insights.takeaway: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by a net external force.

insights.title: Second Law of Motion (Law of Acceleration)
insights.takeaway: The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass. This is represented by the equation F = ma.

insights.title: Third Law of Motion (Law of Action and Reaction)
insights.takeaway: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. This means that when one object exerts a force on another object, the second object exerts an equal but oppositely directed force back on the first.

cards.front: What are Newton's three laws of motion?
cards.back:
1. An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
2. The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.
3. For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

insights.title: Newton's Laws of Motion Insight
insights.takeaway: Newton's first law (law of inertia) states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by a net external force; Newton's second law (F=ma) relates the acceleration of an object to its mass and the applied force, and Newton's third law (action-reaction law) states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
